posts.name: Arjun Bhatia
posts.cooked:
We are looking for a robot cart to replace our cheap hardware store dolly. It needs to work fine, but it must have a handle and foldable casters that can handle gravel or uneven pavement, which we frequently encounter during event load-in. We prefer something affordable and ready-to-buy-off-the-shelf. Building a SuperCart isn’t necessary; we just need a lightweight, compact option that a high school student can lift (~10 kg).

Our main requirements are:
- A handle that extends upward for easy maneuvering
- Folds flat, as we don’t have a trailer or van, only 1-2 SUVs for load-in/out
- Lightweight enough for one student to lift (~10 kg)
- Allowed on the field under the 2025 E706 rules
- Width of about 16 inches (swerve wheels overhang for testing drivetrains)
- Load rating of at least 300 lbs
- Budget of $250 CAD ($175 USD)

Nice-to-have features include:
- A lift platform (unlikely due to size, weight, and budget constraints)
- All four swivel casters for easier movement around the pit (most carts have two fixed and two swivel)

Current candidates:
- Cosco Shifter folding hand truck
- VEVO aluminum hand truck (likely too flimsy for supporting 400 lbs in the middle when extended)

link_counts.title: Shifter Multi-Position Folding Hand Truck and Cart - Cosco

posts.name: Chris Maupin
posts.cooked: Costco offers an upgraded version of its Cosco hand truck, which has been very successful over the past three years. We purchased another one recently to transport our demo robot to various trade shows. The link takes you to the specific product page.

posts.name: Chase Eid
posts.cooked: We built one as a fun project, and it turned out exceptionally well.

posts.name: Lachlan
posts.cooked: Due to popular request, Team 2910 is excited to release its CAD for their current robot cart. The cart needed an update due to its dire need, so it was designed to store inside itself for transportation, carry 3 batteries, accommodate 5 water bottles for the drive team, and support the driver station during operation. Please contact us if you have any questions. Additionally, we made a replica last year and it proved to be quite effective.

posts.name: Ian Osborn
posts.cooked:
A bit of advice on casters: avoid cheap options. You’ll likely need wheels of at least 5-6 inches and around four times the load capacity of your weights. Maybe opt for 4-inch wheels if you prefer premium quality.

Importance lies in selecting durable casters. Cheaper 2-inch casters from hardware stores won’t hold up well for rolling over door thresholds. Each year, teams break their casters at competitions due to poor quality choices.

Our setup uses a Harbor Freight ATV/UTV winch paired with delrin blocks for smooth slides on a fixed frame. Forks move up and down the frame, powered by a 12VDC winch matching the robot’s battery voltage.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
There are two ways to handle robots: one involves simply moving the robot, and the other uses a work platform attached to the robot that also lowers it. For the first method, you can modify a hand truck with extended feet that fit between the robot wheels. Adding a tapered block behind ensures minimal clearance under the robot’s belly pan and bumpers. When breaking it over, the back wheels rise higher. A Fancy version includes folding extensions for storage in cars.  

This image shows a detailed view of a hand truck modification.  

This image illustrates a different design concept.  

This image displays another modification idea.  

The vergo industrial aluminum convertible hand truck offers 3-in-1 functionality. It features a heavy-duty aluminum frame, ergonomic handle, extendable loop, and versatile dolly.  

Here’s the full specs: 750 lb capacity, lightweight frame, ergonomic handle, extendable loop, 3 positions, 53-inch high.  

The price is $249.00.  

Another option involves a hand truck with wheels that lower the robot. However, making the footprint small causes strain over cable protectors. A Vevor motorcycle jack platform helps adjust height, while low-cost tools like battery boxes and inverters assist in lifting. The setup requires more space.  

This image shows a lift setup.  

An alternative is a hand-powered forklift-like device called a stacker. It keeps loads stable by preventing tipping. While effective, it’s heavy and difficult to transport. Hydraulic versions exist, but customization might reduce size.  

This image depicts a stacker option.

link_counts.title: Vergo Industrial Convertible Hand Truck - AS7A2 Heavy Duty Aluminum 3 in 1 Dolly (750 lb Capacity) Lightweight Frame, Ergonomic Handle, Extendable Loop, Versatile Moving Dolly (3 Positions, 53" High) - Amazon.com

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked: A lift platform is a great-to-have feature. Keeping the robot low for load/unload and transportation while maintaining a higher position for inspection and maintenance is ideal. Here’s an option from the USA that meets most specifications: the Franklin Hydraulic Table Cart. Features include a handle, easy removal of the foot pump lever, though the cart isn’t lightweight, making it suitable for two students. It fits field size requirements when the pump lever is attached, but it can still be transported with the lever in the pit for full compliance. The cart measures 17.75 inches wide, has a 500-pound load capacity, and costs $250.

posts.name: Everett33
posts.cooked: While shopping around, be aware that the caster wheels can also be too large of a diameter on a robot cart. We currently use this ULine cart with 8-inch wheels, and it rolls around too easily, because the cart and robot only weigh 220 pounds combined. It rolls so easily that our robot almost didn’t make it back to Michigan in one piece after Champs this year because it started to roll away while on the loading dock. Luckily a 1023 mentor chased it down before total chaos occurred.
